revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Dmitri Borgmann | image = Dmitri Borgmann (1964).png | imagesize = 146px | alt = | caption = Borgmann in a 1964 portrait by Jeff Lowenthal | birth_name = Dmitri Alfred Borgmann | birth_date = {{Birth date|1927|10|22}} | birth_place = [[Berlin]], [[Weimar Republic]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1985|12|7|1927|10|22}} | death_place = [[Dayton, Washington]], US | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = [[Logology (linguistics)|Logology]] | occupation = }} '''Dmitri Alfred Borgmann''' (October 22, 1927 – December 7, 1985) was a German-American author best known for his work in [[Logology (linguistics)|recreational linguistics]].
== Early life == Borgmann was born on October 22, 1927 in [[Berlin]], Germany, to Hans and Lisa Borgmann. Fearing that the Nazi government would discover Lisa's Jewish ancestry, the family fled to the United States in 1936, and settled in [[Chicago]].<ref name="baechler" /><ref name="father" /><ref name="eugene" /> Borgmann graduated from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1946 and found work as an [[actuary]]. In 1964 he quit his job to focus on his writing.<ref name="baechler" /><ref name="father" /><ref name="newsweek" /> In 1971 he started his own research and manuscript writing business, INTELLEX, which employed up to 15 writers at a time to [[ghost writer|ghost-write]] and edit short stories, academic books, and TV and movie scripts. Borgmann eventually relocated the company and his family to [[Dayton, Washington]].<ref name="baechler" /><ref name="eugene" /><ref name="whoswhof" /><ref name="whoswhow" />
== Writing career == Borgmann first attracted media attention for his skill with words in 1958, when over the course of eight weeks he defeated 22 challengers in a row on [[WGN-TV]]'s ''It's In The Name'', winning nearly $3,800.<ref name="baechler" /><ref name="damn" /><ref name="borgmann" /> Around this time he also started contributing word puzzles and trivia to "Line o' Type or Two", a column in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. Much of this material was mined from back issues of ''The Enigma'', the official journal of the [[National Puzzlers' League]] which he had joined in 1956.<ref name="damn" /> By 1964 he had established himself as "the country's leading authority on word play",<ref name="newsweek" /><ref name="gardner" /> a designation he continued to hold up until the time of his death.<ref name="semiotica" />
His first book, ''[[Language on Vacation: An Olio of Orthographical Oddities]]'', was published by [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner's]] in 1965, and received critical acclaim from major magazines and literary journals, including ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and ''[[Scientific American]]''.<ref name="time" /><ref name="kirkus" /><ref name="newman" /> Today it is best remembered for popularizing the word ''[[logology (linguistics)|logology]]'' to refer to the field of recreational linguistics; Borgmann himself is often referred to now as the "Father of Logology".<ref name="morice" /><ref name="evans" /><ref name="johnson" /><ref name="dance" />
The publicity generated by ''Language on Vacation'' led to Borgmann being contracted by industrial design firm [[Raymond Loewy|Loewy]] & Snaith to invent brand names for their clients. For this work he is widely cited as the creator of "[[Exxon]]", which [[Standard Oil]] adopted as its new name after paying Borgmann a $10,000 fee.<ref name="baechler" /><ref name="eugene" /><ref name="omni" /> At $2000 per letter, commentators joked that this made Borgmann the most highly paid writer in history.<ref name="damn" /><ref name="omni" /><ref name="morris" /> ''Language on Vacation'' also attracted the attention of puzzle author [[Martin Gardner]], who in 1967 recommended Borgmann as the editor for [[Greenwood Periodicals]]'s new magazine ''[[Word Ways: The Journal of Recreational Linguistics]]''. Borgmann edited the magazine for its inaugural year, but resigned after Greenwood refused to meet his salary demands.<ref name="damn" /><ref name="abrahams" /> When Greenwood appointed fellow logologist [[Howard W. Bergerson]] to succeed him as editor-in-chief, Borgmann refused to ever speak to him again.<ref name="legend" />
A follow-up to ''Language on Vacation'', entitled ''[[Beyond Language: Adventures in Word and Thought]]'', was published in 1967; it was less successful but still attracted favorable reviews.<ref name="damn" /><ref name="kirkus2" /><ref name="timebeyond" /> Borgmann also edited and annotated a book on [[crossword puzzle]]s, 1970's ''Curious Crosswords''. Throughout the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s he was a regular writer for ''The Chicago Tribune'', ''[[Games (magazine)|Games]]'', and ''[[Puzzle Lovers Newspaper]]'', and continued to contribute articles to ''Word Ways''.<ref name="whoswhof" /><ref name="whoswhow" /><ref name="damn" /> (Much of this writing was published under pseudonyms, including El Uqsor, Jezebel Q. XIXX, Ramona J. Quincunx, and Prof. Merlin X. Houdini.)<ref name="damn" /><ref name="pseudonyms" /> He also sponsored "Jackpot Jubilee", a series of word contests.<ref name="whoswhof" /><ref name="whoswhow" /><ref name="damn" />
== Later life and death == In the late 1970s Borgmann founded a [[new religious movement]], the Divine Immortality Church, and took out ads in ''[[New Times (magazine)|New Times]]'', ''[[The Atlantic]]'', ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' and other magazines, offering [[ordainment]] certificates and [[Doctor of Divinity|divinity degree]]s.<ref name="religion" /><ref name="mother" /><ref name="atlantic" /><ref name="newtimes" /> He also advertised the church in ''[[Hustler]]'', encouraging the publisher to omit the first T in "Immortality". As many as a hundred people joined the movement.<ref name="legend" />
Borgmann had a reputation for being reclusive to the point of [[Eccentricity (behavior)|eccentricity]], a characteristic which intensified in his later years. None of his colleagues from publishing—not even his literary agent [[Joseph Madachy]], nor Martin Gardner, who got Borgmann the editorship of ''Word Ways''—ever met him personally. His successors at ''Word Ways'', Howard W. Bergerson and [[A. Ross Eckler, Jr.]], never met him either.<ref name="omni" /> Borgmann's home life was even more secluded; most external and internal windows were boarded up or covered with heavy drapes, and [[mirror]]s were not permitted in the house. Borgmann rarely left his cluttered upstairs room, sometimes working secretively for weeks without seeing his family. Though he was diagnosed with a heart condition, he refused to take his prescribed medication, and eventually succumbed to a [[heart attack]] on December 7, 1985.<ref name="morris" /><ref name="legend" /> He was survived by his wife of 23 years, Iris Sterling, and their two sons, Mark and Keith.<ref name="father" />
After his death, Eckler and Borgmann's son Keith went through his papers, finding material for a number of articles which were published posthumously in ''Word Ways''.<ref name="father" /> Nineteen folders containing Borgmann's correspondence with Martin Gardner, dating from 1956 to the 1980s, were collected and are preserved in the Special Collections and University Archives of the [[Stanford University Libraries]].<ref name="hartwig" />
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |title=Language on Vacation: An Olio of Orthographical Oddities |first= Dmitri A. |last=Borgmann |location=New York |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |oclc=8478220 |year=1965 |title-link= Language on Vacation: An Olio of Orthographical Oddities }} *{{cite book |title=Beyond Language: Adventures in Word and Thought |first= Dmitri A. |last=Borgmann |location=New York |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |oclc=655067975 |year=1967 |title-link= Beyond Language: Adventures in Word and Thought }} *{{cite book |title=Curious Crosswords |editor-first= Dmitri A. |editor-last=Borgmann |location=New York |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |oclc= |year=1970 }}
